actions.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.
Committee on Foreign Relations. Hearings held.
Committee on Foreign Relations. Ordered to be reported without amendment unfavorably.
Committee on Foreign Relations. Reported to Senate by Senator Pell unfavorably without amendment. Without written report.
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 54.
Measure laid before Senate by unanimous consent.
Considered by Senate.
Considered by Senate.
Passed Senate with amendments by Voice Vote.
Received in the House.
Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Committee Hearings Held.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Ordered to be Reported (Amended).
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Foreign Affairs. H. Rept. 101-71.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 42.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 165 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of S.J. Res. 113 with 2 hours of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. It shall be in order to consider the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Foreign Affairs now printed in the joint resolution as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order. No amendment to said substitute shall be in order except the amendments printed in the report of the Committee on Rules accompanying this resolution, which shall be considered in the order specified in the report and if offered by (1) Representative Solomon or his designee, and (2) Representative Bruce or his designee. Debate on said amendments is limited to the time specified in the re...
Rule H. Res. 165 passed House.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 165.

Rule provides for consideration of S.J. Res. 113 with 2 hours of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. It shall be in order to consider the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Foreign Affairs now printed in the joint resolution as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order. No amendment to said substitute shall be in order except the amendments printed in the report of the Committee on Rules accompanying this resolution, which shall be considered in the order specified in the report and if offered by (1) Representative Solomon or his designee, and (2) Representative Bruce or his designee. Debate on said amendments is limited to the time specified in the re...
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 165 and Rule XXIII.
The Speaker designated the Honorable William J. Hughes to act as Chairman of the Committee.
GENERAL DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H.Res. 165, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with two hours of general debate.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H.Res. 165 the Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of debate on the Solomon amendment.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 165, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of debate on the Bruce amendment.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report S.J. Res. 113.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 165, S.J. Res. 113 is considered passed House.
Mr. Broomfield moved to recommit with instructions to Foreign Affairs.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with ten minutes of debate on the motion to recommit with instructions which seeks to reinstate the text of the Solomon amendment previously agreed to. The Solomon amendment strikes all of the provisions of the committee-reported resolution and substitutes language which expresses the sense of the Congress that the United States Government should not proceed to give final approval to the FSX co-development project.
PREVIOUS QUESTION ON MOTION TO RECOMMIT - By unanimous consent, the previous question was ordered on the motion to recommit with instructions.
On motion to recommit with instructions Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 169 - 247 (Roll no. 80).
On passage Passed by recorded vote: 241 - 168 (Roll no. 81).
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TITLE - By unanimous consent the committee amendment to the title is disagreed to.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Cleared for White House.
Measure Signed in Senate.
Presented to President.
Veto message received in Senate. Ordered held at the desk.
Vetoed by President.
Veto message considered in Senate.
Failed of passage in Senate over veto by Yea-Nay Vote. 66-34. Record Vote No: 175.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.

official_title: A joint resolution prohibiting the export of technology, defense articles, and defense services to codevelop or coproduce the FSX aircraft with Japan.

summary.text: Expresses the sense of the Congress that if the United States and Japan seek to coproduce the FSX aircraft, the President, in negotiating the coproduction memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Japan, should secure provisions that would: (1) prohibit the transfer to Japan of critical engine technologies, including, but not limited to, hot section and digital fuel control technologies; and (2) provide a U.S. share of the total production value of the coproduction of not less than 40 percent, including the value of manufacturing spare parts and other support items of such aircraft system. Conditions U.S. cooperation with Japan in the codevelopment of the FSX aircraft on the requirement that no technical data, defense service, or defense article valued at $50,000,000 or more nor any major defense equipment valued at $14,000,000 or more developed from U.S. technology may be transferred to a third country without prior congressional approval. Requires the Comptroller General, beginning six months after enactment of this Act and every 12 months thereafter, to submit to the Congress a report specifying certain information and describing the progress made in implementing the FSX Codevelopment MOU and related documents. Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to review the MOU or related agreement, and recommend action to the President, if he or she determines that such agreement or its implementation do not serve U.S. strategic commercial interests. Prohibits the implementation of the MOU if the President determines that it is likely to have an adverse impact on the international competitive position of U.S. industry outweighing the benefits of entering into it.

titles.title: A joint resolution prohibiting the export of technology, defense articles, and defense services to codevelop or coproduce the FSX aircraft with Japan.
